there seems to be a lot of dislike towards JIRA for managing software projects. Serious question, what aspect is most disliked about JIRA and what alternatives are used?
<http://keep.google.com|keep.google.com> ? :troll:
the poor agile method

The problem is not JIRA its the tendancy not to apply the spine-model. can't remember who coined the spine model (help please lol).

Basically discussions should not start with he tool that should be used rather with the NEED that has to be filled. Yet often its the otherway around.

In my experience problems arise where people paint themselves into a corner when they configure JIRA workflows or permissions or something they don't understand well enough.
ito feature set yes.
jira is not friendly to developers and managers. The people it should be.
youtracks boards (ala kanban/cards) are amazing for visually communicating, and you have all the happy of a real issue tracker + integrations
Scrum Masters love Jira because they can fiddle
they can add tons of more priority levels
(each meaning “critical”)
create complex and inscrutible workflows
and watch their lovely burn rate charts

I like just having a freeform kanban tool with Trello - we can see exactly where our work is at any time and see where things are starting to choke up. So far I haven’t felt the need for complex estimation/time tracking tools. We abandoned PivotalTracker ages ago.

text: <@U0CE8P0G3>: not sure how sarcastic you were being, your comment would be taken as offensive by a lot of good scrum masters and agile coaches i know

<@U03KJ49CH>: jira is a very heavy handed approach and tool, lots of config. Very complex. What often happens is the focus shifts from being effective and delivering value to becoming a slave to the tool

Biggest  issue I've seen, and it's not exclusive to jira, rather exacerbated by it, is people use it as a communication tool instead of a planning /coordinating /auditing tool. Oh, look at all these fields, I must fill them in. Because I've filled them in, I've communicated with my team. It's a particularly bad tool for communication (low bandwidth high latency)

The whole original intent behind user stories is to have high bandwidth low latency conversations that end in shared understanding. Product people who spend a lot of time writing lots of text in jira and other tools, then handing those over is a bad anti pattern. Not too different to large brs docs in days of old.

That kind of scenario is a barrier to effective communication and shared understanding because 'just look at the story in jira, everything you need to know is there'. Screw collaboration, screw shared understanding, just take my order and do it
My ideal: physical board, low batch size /wip, frequent in person discussions around a whiteboard
If you need an audit trail, eg for tax benefit claims for R&D, document the work done post - fact, ie after its been delivered. Then it matters less what tool you use
<@U1NHGDJTT>: <@U04AAKBBX> and <@U04B2EFED> are the originators of the Spine Model
Apologies to all for this hijack and thanks for letting me write what probably should be a blog post here :simple_smile:
<@U04GQ2MEH>: thanks for the thoughtful insights. Low bandwidth high latency is the thought for the day

I had a similar challenge in $previous_job… I was a huge proponent of pivotal tracker because it did very very little, and its biggest strength was automating cadence, which is something a computer can do better than us after all. they went with jira for a lot of the reasons Josh mentioned above. completely missed the point.
<@U0348JC5Y> my pleasure. hope you enjoyed reading it
